qas.question: What three noun genders does Serbo-Croatian have?
Where are adjectives properly placed in the Serbo-Croatian language?

answers.text: in front of the noun they modify

qas.question: Which number in the Serbo-Croatian language is treated as an adjective?
What three genders does Slovene have?
What type of numbers are in Russian?
What are the three numbers treated as in Slavic languages?

plausible_answers.text: in front of the noun they modify

qas.question: In Russian where are adjectives placed?
In Slavic languages what must singular and plural numbers do when in front of a noun?

context: Like most Slavic languages, there are mostly three genders for nouns: <a0_0><b3_0>masculine, feminine, and neuter<b3_0/><a0_0/>, a distinction which is still present even in the plural (unlike Russian and, in part, the Čakavian dialect). They also have two numbers: <b4_0>singular and plural<b4_0/>. However, some consider there to be three numbers (paucal or dual, too), since (still preserved in closely related Slovene) after two (dva, dvije/dve), three (tri) and four (četiri), and all numbers ending in them (e.g. twenty-two, ninety-three, one hundred four) the genitive singular is used, and after all other numbers five (pet) and up, the genitive plural is used. (The number <a2_0>one [jedan]<a2_0/> is treated as <b5_0>an adjective<b5_0/>.) Adjectives are placed <a1_0><b6_0>in front of the noun they modify<b6_0/><a1_0/> and <b7_0>must agree<b7_0/> in both case and number with it.
